TEXT.P: Draw a graph of this data by pressing "Plot the Data."
Notice that there are no lines drawn between the points. This type of graph is called a scatter plot: a simple placement of points for each data row with no lines connecting them.

In the graphs from Steps 1 and 2 there was a sequence through time from one point to another. We used a line plot for those situations. Measuring a variable that changes with distance from a fixed point would also call for a line plot.
For the data set at left we have no reason to assume any sequence between the points. In fact, we don't know what year each point represents. In this case, a scatter plot is appropriate.
